message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Robust Time-Varying Formation Control of One-Sided Lipschitz Nonlinear Multiagent System With Delays via Optimization Algorithm
Paper Abstract: This article develops a novel robust control methodology for nonlinear multiagent systems (MASs) to address the time-varying formation (TVF) problem. The methodology offers a concise yet efficacious technique based on the Lyapunov functional for more general one-sided Lipschitz (OSL) nonlinear MASs with external disturbances and time-varying delays. Note that most existing TVF controllers can only achieve formation targets under small delays, which significantly limits their performance. The proposed TVF control method in this article demonstrates remarkable robustness by effectively accommodating larger delays and additionally mitigating the impact of disturbances on MASs. On this basis, a robust TVF controller optimization scheme of MASs combined with the particle swarm optimization (PSO) algorithm is proposed. Comparing the optimized results with those under conventional control methods, it has been proved that optimized controller has obvious improvement on the formation performance of MASs. Finally, the feasibility and the superiority of the developed TVF control approach are validated by a simulation of an autonomous aerial vehicle swarm system (AAVSS) composed of six AAVs.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Lyapunov functional"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_optimization"},{"title":"Lyapunov exponent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_exponent"},{"title":"Lyapunov fractal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_fractal"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Lyapunov vector - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_vector"},{"title":"Lyapunov–Schmidt reduction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov–Schmidt_reduction"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of Lyapunov functionals and related concepts:

## Lyapunov Functions

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## How Lyapunov Functions Work

The Direct Method makes use of a Lyapunov function V(x) which has an analogy to the potential function of classical dynamics. The basic idea is that if you can find a function that decreases along trajectories of a system, you can prove stability. A Lyapunov function is a nonnegative scalar measure of a multi-dimensional state, and typically, the function is defined to grow large when the system moves towards undesirable states.

## Applications

For certain classes of ODEs, the existence of Lyapunov functions is a necessary and sufficient condition for stability. Beyond stability analysis, Lyapunov optimization refers to the use of a Lyapunov function to optimally control a dynamical system, and Lyapunov functions are used extensively in control theory to ensure different forms of system stability.

The search results primarily address Lyapunov functions in ODEs and dynamical systems; if you need information specifically about Lyapunov functionals in functional differential equations or partial differential equations, please let me know.

## Lyapunov Functions

In the theory of ordinary differential equations (ODEs), Lyapunov functions, named after Aleksandr Lyapunov, are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ODE.(no content)Lyapunov functions (also called Lyapunov's second method for stability) are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.

## How Lyapunov Functions Work

The Direct Method makes use of a Lyapunov function V(x) which has an analogy to the potential function of classical dynamics. The basic idea is that if you can find a function that decreases along trajectories of a system, you can prove stability. A Lyapunov function is a nonnegative scalar measure of a multi-dimensional state, and typically, the function is defined to grow large when the system moves towards undesirable states.

## Applications

Web search results for query: "multiagent systems"

Links: [{"title":"Multi-agent system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_system"},{"title":"Autonomous Agents and Multi-Agent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_Agents_and_Multi-Agent_Systems"},{"title":"International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_Conference_on_Autonomous_Agents_and_Multiagent_Systems"},{"title":"Distributed multi-agent reasoning system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distributed_multi-agent_reasoning_system"},{"title":"Agent-oriented software engineering - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Agent-oriented_software_engineering"},{"title":"Katia Sycara - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Katia_Sycara"},{"title":"Peter Stone (professor) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peter_Stone_(professor)"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Multi-agent planning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_planning"},{"title":"Wassim Michael Haddad - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wassim_Michael_Haddad"}]

## Search Results for "Multiagent Systems"

I've found comprehensive information about multiagent systems. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Core Concept

A multi-agent system (MAS) is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

### Key Characteristics

Agents in a multi-agent system have important characteristics including autonomy (agents are at least partially independent and self-aware), local views (no agent has a full global view), and decentralization (no single agent controls the system).

### Agents and Composition

While multi-agent systems research typically refers to software agents, the agents could equally well be robots, humans or human teams.(no content)Intelligence may include methodic, functional, procedural approaches, algorithmic search or reinforcement learning.

### Recent Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

### Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

### Research and Community

The International Conference on Autonomous Agents and Multiagent Systems (AAMAS) is the leading scientific conference for research in the areas of artificial intelligence, autonomous agents, and multiagent systems.

Web search results for query: "autonomous aerial vehicles"

Links: [{"title":"Unmanned aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"Autonomous aircraft - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_aircraft"},{"title":"Unmanned combat aerial vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_combat_aerial_vehicle"},{"title":"eVTOL - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/EVTOL"},{"title":"List of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Personal air vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Personal_air_vehicle"},{"title":"Micro air vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Micro_air_vehicle"},{"title":"Unmanned ground vehicle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_ground_vehicle"},{"title":"History of unmanned aerial vehicles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_unmanned_aerial_vehicles"},{"title":"Urban air mobility - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Urban_air_mobility"}]

I've completed a web search for "autonomous aerial vehicles." Here's a summary of the key findings:

## Overview

An autonomous aircraft is an aircraft which flies under the control of on-board autonomous robotic systems and needs no intervention from a human pilot or remote control.(no content)Unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) or unmanned aircraft systems (UAS), commonly known as drones, are aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather are controlled remotely or are autonomous.

## Technology and Capabilities

Autonomous drones employ a host of advanced technologies that allow them to carry out their missions without human intervention, such as cloud computing, computer vision, artificial intelligence, machine learning, deep learning, and thermal sensors.(no content)The flight of UAVs may operate under remote control by a human operator, as remotely piloted aircraft (RPA), or with various degrees of autonomy, such as autopilot assistance, up to fully autonomous aircraft that have no provision for human intervention.

## Applications

Urban air mobility (UAM) refers to the use of small, highly automated aircraft for the transportation of passengers or cargo at low altitudes within urban and suburban areas. The term generally refers to existing and emerging technologies such as traditional helicopters, vertical-takeoff-and-landing aircraft (VTOL), electrically propelled vertical-takeoff-and-landing aircraft (eVTOL), and unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs).

## Development and Future

A number of air taxis are under development and larger autonomous transports are also being planned. However, some modern drones have a high degree of autonomy, although they are not fully capable and the regulatory environment prohibits their widespread use in civil aviation.

Links: [{"title":"Lipschitz continuity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lipschitz_continuity"},{"title":"Lipschitz domain - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lipschitz_domain"},{"title":"Talk:Lipschitz continuity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Lipschitz_continuity"},{"title":"Absolute continuity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Absolute_continuity"},{"title":"Continuous function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Continuous_function"},{"title":"Kirszbraun theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kirszbraun_theorem"},{"title":"Rademacher's theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rademacher's_theorem"},{"title":"Uniform continuity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uniform_continuity"},{"title":"Rudolf Lipschitz - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolf_Lipschitz"},{"title":"Bounded operator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bounded_linear_operator"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Lipschitz continuity:

## Definition

Lipschitz continuity, named after German mathematician Rudolf Lipschitz, is a strong form of uniform continuity for functions.(no content)A Lipschitz continuous function is limited in how fast it can change: there exists a real number such that, for every pair of points, the function's output change is bounded by a constant times the input change.

More formally, a function f : X → Y between two metric spaces is called Lipschitz continuous if there exists a real constant K ≥ 0 such that, for all x₁ and x₂ in X, the distance between outputs is at most K times the distance between inputs. Any such K is referred to as a Lipschitz constant for the function f.

## Key Properties

- Every Lipschitz continuous map between two metric spaces is uniformly continuous.

- There exists a chain of strict inclusions: Continuously differentiable ⊂ Lipschitz continuous ⊂ absolutely continuous ⊂ uniformly continuous ⊂ continuous.

- An everywhere differentiable function is Lipschitz continuous (with K = sup |g′(x)|) if and only if it has a bounded first derivative.

- A Lipschitz function is absolutely continuous and therefore is differentiable almost everywhere. Its derivative is essentially bounded in magnitude by the Lipschitz constant.

## Special Cases

If K = 1 the function is called a short map, and if 0 ≤ K < 1 and f maps a metric space to itself, the function is called a contraction.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "particle swarm optimization"

Links: [{"title":"Particle swarm optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Particle_swarm_optimization"},{"title":"Multi-swarm optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-swarm_optimization"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Swarm behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_behaviour"},{"title":"Maurice Clerc (mathematician) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maurice_Clerc_(mathematician)"}]

## Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO)

Particle swarm optimization (PSO) is a computational method that optimizes a problem by iteratively trying to improve a population of candidate solutions with regard to a given measure of quality.(no content)It solves a problem through interactions among a population of candidate solutions, dubbed particles, moving the particles around in the search-space according to simple mathematical formulae that adjust each particle's position and velocity.

### How It Works

Each particle's movement is influenced by its own best known position so far, and by the best known position in its topological neighborhood (which may include the entire population if so specified); vectors are updated as better positions are found.(no content)At each time iteration, the particle swarm optimiser accelerates each particle toward its optimum locations according to simple mathematical rules.

### Origins and Inspiration

It was developed in 1995 by Kennedy and Eberhart and was first aimed at simulating the social behaviour and choreography of bird flocks and fish schools.

### Key Characteristics

PSO is a metaheuristic as it makes few or no assumptions about the problem being optimized and can search very large spaces of candidate solutions. However, metaheuristics such as PSO do not guarantee an optimal solution is ever found.(no content)The main advantage of such an approach over other global minimization strategies such as simulated annealing is that the large number of members that make up the particle swarm make the technique impressively resilient to the problem of local minima.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've completed a web search for "nonlinear systems control." Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)Nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle and applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

## Key Characteristics

Nonlinear systems are often governed by nonlinear differential equations, and the mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle them are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems.

## Analysis and Design Techniques

Mathematical techniques for handling nonlinear systems include limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions. Additionally, if only solutions near a stable point are of interest, nonlinear systems can often be linearized by approximating them by a linear system obtained by expanding the nonlinear solution in a series, and then linear techniques can be used.(no content)Nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

## Practical Applications

Even if the plant is linear, a nonlinear controller can often have attractive features such as simpler implementation, faster speed, more accuracy, or reduced control energy, which justify the more difficult design procedure.

Modern approaches to nonlinear control include feedback linearization, which is a common strategy employed in nonlinear control to control nonlinear systems, and nonlinear model predictive control (NMPC), which is a variant of model predictive control that is characterized by the use of nonlinear system models in the prediction.

## Analysis Complete ✅

I have successfully analyzed the paper on "Robust Time-Varying Formation Control of One-Sided Lipschitz Nonlinear Multiagent System With Delays via Optimization Algorithm" and completed all validation steps.

### Summary of Findings:

**Paper Classification:** `contribution`
- The paper proposes novel control methodologies and optimization schemes for time-varying formation control.

**Identified Triples (6 total):**

1. **Lyapunov function** (method, uses) - Used for proving stability of the control system
2. **Particle swarm optimization** (method, proposes) - Proposed as the optimization algorithm for the TVF controller
3. **Multi-agent system** (concept, uses) - The core system being controlled
4. **Lipschitz continuity** (concept, uses) - Extends to one-sided Lipschitz nonlinear systems
5. **Nonlinear control** (method, uses) - The core methodology being developed
6. **Unmanned aerial vehicle** (tool, uses) - Application domain for validation via swarm simulation

### Validation Results:
- ✅ All 6 triples successfully validated
- ✅ All Wikipedia URLs verified and accessible
- ✅ Proper entity type classification (3 methods, 2 concepts, 1 tool)
- ✅ Relation types correctly assigned (5 "uses", 1 "proposes")
- ✅ Requirements met: Contribution paper with at least 1 "proposes" and 1+ "uses"
